subsections.title: 1.1 The Global Food Challenge and the Role of Irrigation
subsections.point1: • The challenge of feeding a growing population with finite resources
subsections.point2: • The role and importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity
subsections.point3: • The necessity of scalable water-efficient practices for increasing food demand

subsections.title: 1.2 Traditional Irrigation: Limitations and the Need for Automation
subsections.point1: • Definition of irrigation scheduling and management
subsections.point2: • Historical irrigation management techniques (e.g., manual and timer-based scheduling)
subsections.point3: • Limitations: labor-intensive, inefficient water use, less adaptable to changing conditions
subsections.point4: • Need for scalable, automated solutions for greater efficiency

subsections.title: 1.3 The Emergence of Smart Irrigation Management and IoT
subsections.point1: • Contrast between modern and historical irrigation management, emphasizing automation
subsections.point2: • Technologies for smart irrigation management (e.g., remote sensing, sensor networks, weather data, and computational algorithms)
subsections.point3: • Key point: modern approaches rely on vast data and analysis algorithms
subsections.point4: • The role of IoT in collecting vast amounts of data through sensors, data transmission, and tailored networks
subsections.point5: • The importance of real-time data for dynamic irrigation systems and automated management at a larger scale
subsections.point6: • Challenges hampering the full benefit of IoT: processing diverse data sources, data integration, and lack of integrated data analysis

subsections.title: 1.4 Machine Learning and Real-time/Automated Systems in Irrigation Management
subsections.point1: • Machine learning (ML) in processing vast data, predicting plant stress, modeling climate effects, and optimizing irrigation
subsections.point2: • ML's potential constrained by manual steps (data interpretation, decision-making on irrigation timing and volume, and system adjustments)
subsections.point3: • The need for automating ML integration to allow direct action from insights to irrigation execution, removing bottlenecks and achieving real-time adaptability
subsections.point4: • The current fragmented approach in smart irrigation due to focusing on pieces rather than the entire picture
subsections.point5: • The need for automating and integrating each section of the irrigation management pipeline for autonomous real-time end-to-end irrigation management
subsections.point6: • Full autonomous irrigation management pipeline: sensor/weather data -> transmission -> processing/analysis -> algorithmic decision-making -> automated action
subsections.point7: • Benefits of automation: easing bottlenecks in data collection, insight generation, and processing; freeing up labor and fostering scalability

subsections.title: 1.5 Interoperability and Standardization: Key Enablers for Seamless Integration
subsections.point1: • The critical role of interoperability and standardization in enabling seamless integration across the automated irrigation management system
subsections.point2: • Challenges of integrating heterogeneous data sources, devices, and systems
subsections.point3: • Standardized protocols and data formats as essential for achieving seamless integration and ensuring compatibility between components
subsections.point4: • Existing and emerging standards (e.g., OGC SensorThings API, ISO 11783) and their applicability to real-time irrigation management systems

subsections.title: 1.6 Objectives of the Review
subsections.point1: • Primary Objective: To critically evaluate the current state and future potential of real-time, end-to-end automated irrigation management systems that integrate IoT and machine learning technologies for enhancing agricultural water use efficiency and crop productivity.
subsections.point2: • Specific Objective 1: Examining the automation of each part of the irrigation management pipeline and the seamless integration of each section in the context of irrigation scheduling and management.
subsections.point3: • Specific Objective 2: Analyze the effectiveness and efficiency of integrated end-to-end automated irrigation systems
subsections.point4: • Specific Objective 3: Investigate the role of interoperability and standardization in enabling the integration of components within the automated irrigation management pipeline
subsections.point5: • Specific Objective 4: Identify gaps and propose solutions for seamless integration across the automated irrigation management system, aiming to achieve fully autonomous, scalable irrigation management.
